title: Creative Writing: Getting Started
subject: English
summary: Simple ways to launch creative writing with young learners.
content:
Why it matters:
- Writing grows from oral language, play, and talk.
- Learners benefit from visible models and scaffolds.

Try this:
1) Picture Prompts Circle — Show a rich image. Learners say what they notice; teacher lists words/phrases on the board.
2) Sentence Stems — Provide starters (e.g., 'I opened the door and…'). Learners complete orally, then write.
3) Word Banks — Build themed word lists together before writing (characters, settings, actions).

Support:
- Use quick 'plan, say, write, check' routine.
- Offer frames: Beginning / Middle / Ending.

title: Story Openings: Hooks that Work
subject: English
summary: Teach openings that spark curiosity: action, dialogue, setting, question.
content:
Mini-lesson:
- Model four opening types on the board: Action, Dialogue, Setting, Question.
- Read a few strong examples aloud; ask which type they are.

Activity:
- Learners pick a type and draft two different openings for the same idea.
- Partner swap: partners read and choose which opening makes them want to read on, and why.

Differentiation:
- Provide opening frames (e.g., 'Suddenly, …').
- Use pictures for learners who need more support.

title: Planning Frames (Graphic Organisers)
subject: English
summary: Use simple frames so learners can plan before writing.
content:
Options:
- 3-Box Plan: Beginning / Middle / End.
- 5-Box Plan: Character / Setting / Problem / Events / Ending.
- Story Mountain: build-up, climax, resolution (with pictures).

Tips:
- Model how to sketch quick icons in each box before writing.
- Keep the plan visible while learners write; allow them to point and talk through it.

title: Descriptive Writing: Show, Don’t Tell
subject: English
summary: Move from 'He was scared' to clues that show feelings through actions and senses.
content:
Teach:
- Make a T-chart: TELL vs SHOW. Brainstorm together.
- Model swapping 'tell' sentences for 'show' sentences using senses and actions.

Practice:
- Give learners 3 'tell' sentences to convert to 'show'.
- Build a class word bank for feelings (e.g., 'shaky knees', 'butterflies').

title: Marking Writing: Simple Rubrics
subject: English
summary: Keep criteria clear: idea, structure, sentences, spelling/punctuation—age-appropriate.
content:
Routine:
- Share the rubric before writing; use smiley/traffic-light levels.
- After writing, self-check with the rubric, then partner feedback.

Teacher Tips:
- Give one 'glow' (strength) and one 'grow' (next step).
- Avoid over-marking; focus on the current goal.
